Starting your own business is often exciting and daunting in equal measures.

One minute you’ll be riding high with the thought of being your own boss, the next you’ll be fretting about how to actually get your business off the ground and make it a success.

We caught up with business mentor and author, David Mellor, to get his top tips on starting a business. Watch the videos and you’ll find out what questions to ask yourself before starting out, how to avoid the most common mistakes, and much more.

Since 2001, David Mellor has developed a highly successful portfolio of activities based on his 25 years of commercial and investment banking expertise with HSBC and Deutsche Bank.

David is a recognised expert in his field, regularly speaking at conferences and running seminars and workshops. He holds Associate status at Cass Business School, where he is also an Honorary Senior Visiting Fellow in the Faculty of Finance.

Take-home pay comparison

DAY RATE LIMITED COMPANY – WEEKLY PAY UMBRELLA – WEEKLY PAY
Outside IR35 Inside IR35 (private sector) Inside IR35 (public sector) Worker subject to SDC* Worker not subject to SDC
£250 £996 £807 £885 £785 £834
£300 £1,137 £939 £1,036 £922 £962
£350 £1,277 £1,070 £1,186 £1,040 £1,089
£400 £1,417 £1,202 £1,321 £1,152 £1,201
£450 £1,557 £1,314 £1,421 £1,230 £1,279
£500 £1,683 £1,400 £1,548 £1,334 £1,383
£550 £1,779 £1,507 £1,698 £1,461 £1,510
£600 £1,886 £1,639 £1,843 £1,589 £1,638

*SDC = Supervision, Direction or Control.

General assumptions applicable to all calculations:

  • Based on 2017/18 tax rates (personal allowance of £11,500)
  • Annual accountancy, umbrella and further advice costs (inc VAT) are taken into account
  • Travel expenses of £100 per week to a fixed location for a period of less than 24 months
  • No other income aside from day rate
  • Work schedule of 5 days per week, 52 weeks per year
  • Take home pay rounded to the nearest pound


Limited companies:

  • Single-director limited company
  • VAT Flat rate rate of 14.5%
  • Take-home comprises director’s salary, dividends and reimbursed travel expenses
  • All profits after tax are taken out of the company as dividends
  • Employment allowance not taken into account


Umbrella:

  • IR35 public sector calculations assume the ‘fee payer’ is the agency, who then pays Employers NIC to HMRC
  • Student loans not taken into account

acf.EBB_sub_headline: Free letter templates for chasing overdue invoices
acf.EH_sub_heading: Sort those unpaid invoices and late payments
acf.EH_copy:
Late payment is a constant problem for freelancers, contractors, and small businesses. Often the last link in the supply chain and, consequently, the last to get paid.

That’s not how it should be though. You’re entitled to the exact same payment terms as the largest of businesses. You can also issue the same penalties for overdue invoices in line with your contracts or the protection provided under the Late Payment of Commercial Debt Act.

If you’re struggling with a non-paying client, download our series of late payment reminders and get that invoice paid.

tile_group_posts.post_title: Late Payment Reminder: The Polite Nudge
Late Payment Reminder: The Firm Reminder
Late Payment Reminder: The Final Notice

tile_group.tile_group_title: How and when should I use these templates?
tile_group.tile_group_copy:
If you need to remind your client about an outstanding payment but don’t have a talent for officious-sounding correspondence, these late payment reminders are just what you need.

Letter 1: The polite nudge
Send this by post or email on the day your payment is due, if you haven’t received it. A hard-headed approach to credit control works best – so let your clients know you don’t mess around. Ask for a confirmation of receipt, so you know someone is dealing with it. It’s no good sending chaser letters if your client has moved offices!

Letter 2: The firm reminder
The first letter gives your client seven days to respond, so if a week goes by and you still haven’t been paid (or received a revised payment date), it’s time to fire off this letter. You may choose to send this by recorded post so you can guarantee your client has received it – a proof of receipt could come in useful should things go south.

Letter 3: The final notice
As per the warning in your second letter, if another week goes by without explanation and your bank account is still bare, it’s time to issue some penalties. You’re legally entitled to impose these costs, and don’t accept a client telling you otherwise! Recorded post is your friend here. You’ll get a proof of receipt and it’ll let your client know you mean business (if they didn’t already).

If you need some extra assistance in sorting your unpaid invoices, our debt collection service Crunch Collections can help.

We specialise in helping freelancers, contractors, and small businesses recover unpaid invoices cost-effectively, without alienating clients.

  • No contracts to sign;
  • No money to pay in advance;
  • No hidden charges;
  • No collection, no commission – you only pay if we recover your money.

Get in touch with Crunch Collections today

acf.EBB_sub_headline: Twenty policy ideas to strengthen self-employment and micro-businesses in the UK
acf.BF_title: Related articles

FH_flexible_headline.FH_sub_heading: Examining the past, present, and future of self-employment policy in the UK
FH_flexible_headline.FH_copy:
Self-employment is once again on the rise. The number of people working for themselves has grown by 40 percent since 2000, and is set to reach a record 5 million by the end of the decade.

A debate rages as to whether this is a trend to be lauded or lamented. While some hold that the self-employed are just another legion in a growing army of precariat workers, others hail an entrepreneurial renaissance among spirited self-starters.

Either way, past and present governments have been in a constant battle to stay relevant and lend a helping hand. From tax cuts and deregulation drives, through to welfare changes and a multitude of new business support initiatives, there have been no shortage of pro-entrepreneurial policies.

But how many of these have been effective? Where do policy gaps remain? And is it time for the government to be more interventionist?

In 2016 we partnered with the multi-award winning think tank and charity The RSA to develop twenty policy ideas that government can adopt to help the self-employed and small business owners. We published our findings in February 2017 and will work hard to promote the recommendations to decision-makers across Government.

• Download the full report
  • View the event video
  • Follow the conversation at #SelfEmployment or comment on Medium
  • Join our free Chorus community to receive updates

FH_flexible_headline.FH_copy:
When you’re self-employed, you’ve a lot on your plate. But don’t leave everything at risk by not having adequate business insurance in place.

Being insured will help protect you should the unexpected happen – it’s there to protect you, your clients, and the general public.

Whether you work from home, have your own office, or spend most of your time at client sites, we’ve got business insurance to meet your needs.

What makes us different?

We know the self-employed inside out. Since 2009, self-employed professionals have been trusting us to look after their accounts and we now have over 9,000+ satisfied clients.

Our insurance is designed specifically for the self-employed. We’ve created three packages to make it as easy and quick as possible to get insurance, including cover for professional indemnity, employers’ liability, public liability, and business interruption.

No long forms to fill out, no unnecessary questions, no hassle.

Self-employed employers’ liability insurance

Employers’ liability insurance is there to provide a financial award to any of your employees who are injured or have property damaged while in your employment and during working hours.

Self-employed public liability insurance

As a self-employed professional, public liability insurance protects you, the business owner, against a claim from the public for financial loss, accident, or injury.

Self-employed professional indemnity insurance

Professional indemnity insurance will cover you if a client sues for a financial loss they have suffered as a result of your action or negligent advice.

Self-employed business interruption insurance

Business interruption insurance will mean you don’t lose out financially if you are unable to carry out your work due to a disaster.

FH_flexible_headline.FH_heading: Do I need small business insurance?
FH_flexible_headline.FH_copy:
Running your own business takes a lot of passion, dedication, and investment (of time and money). It’s therefore vital you have the correct insurance in place to cover you if something unexpected happens.

Whether or not an incident is your fault, it could mean the difference between your business staying afloat and going under.

Ultimately, having the correct business insurance policy helps support you, your business, your clients, and the general public should the need arise.

What makes us different?

We understand the needs of small businesses. Using knowledge gained from the 9,000+ satisfied clients who already trust us to look after their accounts, we’ve designed Crunch Insurance from the ground up.

We’ve created three packages to make it as easy and quick as possible to get insurance, including cover for professional indemnity, employers’ liability, public liability, and business interruption.

No long forms to fill out, no unnecessary questions, no hassle.

Small business employers’ liability insurance

Aside from a few exceptions, employers’ liability insurance is mandatory for small businesses. It provides a financial award to a member of your staff who is injured or has property damaged while in your employment during working hours.

Small business public liability insurance

Public liability insurance protects you, the business owner, against a claim from the public for financial loss, accident, or injury. It also protects the public for any accident or injury sustained due to the business.

Small business professional indemnity insurance

Professional indemnity insurance offers protection for small businesses should a customer sue you for a financial loss they believe you caused through your action or negligent advice.

Business interruption insurance for small businesses

If you are unable to carry out your work due to a disaster, business interruption insurance will mean you don’t lose out financially.

acf.PH_sub_heading: What is Making Tax Digital?
acf.PH_copy:
[Updated with latest decisions from Spring Budget 2017]

Making Tax Digital is the Government’s programme to move all personal and business tax online. Starting in 2017, and due to complete in 2020, all of us will be affected by Making Tax Digital (MTD).

The programme is being led by HMRC and Crunch is deeply involved, creating software and solutions to work with the private and public beta passes of MTD.

The Making Tax Digital for Business timetable for all businesses trading over £10,000 is:

  • April 2018 if they have profits chargeable to Income Tax and pay Class 4 National Insurance contributions (NICs), and their turnover is above the VAT registration threshold (£85,000 from 1st April 2017).
  • April 2019 if they are registered for and pay VAT; or have profits chargeable to Income Tax and pay Class 4 National Insurance contribution with turnover below the VAT threshold.
  • April 2020 if they pay Corporation Tax (CT)

We keep you up-to-date on all the latest MTD developments from Crunch and HMRC.

EBB_large_desktop_image.title: 1900x440
EBB_large_desktop_image.alt: Making tax digital on a laptop
EBB_large_desktop_image.name: 1900x440

acf.EBB_sub_headline: Everything you need to know as a micro-business owner
acf.BF_title: Our recent MTD articles on the Crunch Blog...

FH_flexible_headline.FH_copy:
Who will MTD affect?

The MTD for business programme affects everyone with a turnover of more than £10,000 per year. There is a phased approach with the self-employed and landlords being the first group required to use MTD from April 2018.

By April 2020, all businesses over the £10,000/year threshold will need to be using MTD.

For individuals and businesses, there’s a range of exceptions in place for those with disabilities and genuine difficulty getting online. Charities have been completely exempted from the scheme, but any trading companies they operate still are required to comply.

Will I have to do four tax returns each year?

No. Businesses will be required to submit an update once per quarter, followed by an annual submission. The updates will be very simple and, in most cases, will be done automatically by your accounting software.

Thanks to the updates and the greater information integration planned by HMRC, the annual submission should be quicker and simpler than the existing confirmation statement.

Will I need to purchase software?

You will need to use software to submit your quarterly returns, but whether you need to pay for it will depend on the size and nature of your business.

HMRC and the business software industry have agreed that there will be provision of free software packages to serve smaller and simpler businesses.

What if I can’t file digitally?

Extensive provision and support has been planned by HMRC for those who cannot file digitally. The provisions are similar what’s already provided for those unable to use existing HMRC online services.

For example, you may be able to nominate someone to submit the information for you or may be allowed to submit information by phone.

Will I need to keep extra records?

No additional records are needed. The requirement is simply to keep your records digitally using a method that is compatible with the MTD programme.

HMRC will publish a list of providers who offer compatible services.

What are the key benefits?

  • The tax system will be simpler, faster, and more accurate.
  • Those who combine PAYE employed roles with freelancing should see more accurate tax codes on their payslips.
  • Everyone using MTD will be able to see live tax calculations from HMRC.
  • A single online tax account with HMRC will help to save time and enable better budgeting.

What better way to do this than be your own boss? We’re here to help you every step of the way, with inspirational stories and advice from people who have done it themselves, along with jargon-free business guides.

Make 2017 the year you do something different. Something radical. #GetStarted

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: Crunch Chorus: the UK's leading micro-business community.
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
We believe:

  • Micro-businesses matter – there are more micro-businesses than any other kind in the UK, employing 8.4 million people.
  • The tax and benefits system needs reform to reflect the changing economy.
  • Micro-business owners deserve products and services which support their unique needs and ambitions.

We are part of Crunch, the UK’s fastest growing accountancy and services company.

Watch this space for upcoming events.

  • Watch our latest videos!

Our partnership with the multi-award winning think tank and charity The RSA developed twenty policy ideas for government to help the self-employed and small business owners.

We published the report at a high-profile event at RSA House in London and are now presenting the findings to decision-makers across Whitehall.

Find out more, watch the event video and download our report

acf.PH_sub_heading: All your business needs, all in one place
acf.PH_copy:
Finding reliable, competitively priced suppliers and services for your business can be confusing and expensive. That’s why, since we launched in 2009, we’ve been on a mission to hunt down the very best small business providers. Our partners are the perfect fit for micro-businesses, and you’ll find them all in the marketplace.

We have personal relationships with all our marketplace partners, we use many of them ourselves, and we can vouch for the quality of their services.

From business insurance to legal services; from mortgage assistance to freelancer banks – we’ve got everything you need in one place, complete with our seal of approval.

acf.PH_sub_heading: Start a business - it’s easy when you know how
acf.PH_copy:
How often do you wish you could quit your job and follow your dreams?

Well we’ve got news for you…

It’s not as hard as you think!

We’re here to prove to you that with the proper foundations and a bit of hard work, you can be one of the thousands of people getting out there and forging their own path in the world. And you don’t have to do it alone.

We specialise in helping aspiring entrepreneurs (just like you), escape the jobs they hate and do something they’re really passionate about.

Think of this page as a resource with all the ingredients you need to start a business.  We’ll guide you through everything you need to know in the form of plain English – from conceiving an idea to good bookkeeping – so you can take that exciting, life defining leap with confidence.

Whether you want to take it slow, starting a business alongside your day job or you want to jump in head first – you can get started from scratch today and be running your very own business in no time.

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: What's it all about?
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
Everything that was ever great started out as a simple idea. Have you got a solution to a problem? Do you want to earn a living doing what you love? If so, how can you make it unique to the market?

Figure out what you can offer the world and whether people would actually pay for it.

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: Knowledge is power
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
Once you’ve got your idea down, you need to back it up with plenty of research. Knowing all you can about the industry you’re going into, as well as business in general, can mean the difference between success and failure.

Make sure you check out our jargon-free business guides and blog full of practical business advice for beginners and seasoned entrepreneurs alike.

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: Put it all together
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
Your business plan establishes what your business is about, who it’ll serve and, most importantly – how you’ll go about it. It’ll essentially form the framework on which you build your business.

It can also be useful as the outline for your pitch to secure funding or get business partners on board (if you want).

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: Need a cash injection?
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
Unless you’re lucky enough to have some capital behind you, you may want to look into funding options such as grants, loans, investors, and crowdfunding to help get your business on its feet.

Even if you’ve already got everything you need to start a business, it’s always recommended that you keep some cash backed up as a safety net.

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: Make your mark
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
We can’t emphasis enough how building a killer brand is the key to success for any business. Start off by coming up with a great name and logo that communicates what your business is about.

Also make sure you invest in your web and social media presence to directly engage with your audience and convert them into paying clients.

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: Get resourceful
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
Pad out your business with essential services from the Crunch Marketplace. We’ve handpicked the very best partners (complete with exclusive offers) that we trust to gear your new business for success.

Also, remember to make sure you check out our fantastic (and free) business tools such as our professional invoice templates and IR35 calculator.

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: How will you operate?
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
Sole trader or limited company. This determines your responsibilities, how your business will work legally and how you’re taxed. Weigh up the pros and cons depending on how you’d like to do business, then register with HMRC.

If you want to Go Limited, we’ll even form your limited company for you!

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: Get the rates you deserve
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
What price tag should you put on what your business offers? Consider whether you’ll charge a flat fee or an hourly rate? What about your costs, upkeep, and the potential profit for want to make?

Our National Day Rate Calculator will show you average rates of freelancers and contractors in your region, so you get a better idea of what you could charge.

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: Manage the numbers
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
Accounting is a necessary part of business, but can be a daunting prospect for aspiring entrepreneurs. When starting a business you need to work out a system that works for you, or get an accountant on board to help you take care of it.

(Psst… We specialise in helping startups succeed with the perfect small business accounting setup – so you can focus on the fun stuff!)

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: A decision you'll never regret
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
Stop waiting for that mythical right time, and just take the leap! Following these steps, you’ve already laid the groundwork you need to start a business. We know the precipice can be scary, but there’s nothing quite like completely owning your destiny.

Just do it. We promise you it’s worth it.

AH_alternating_headline.AH_heading: Hit the ground running with Crunch
AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: It’s our business to make your business a success
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
We’ve specially developed our service to help startups and small businesses flourish with a combination of simple to use online accounting software and unlimited support from our expert in-house accountants.

Everything you need for easy, hassle free accounting – all in one place.

Why not give our software a whirl for free and see how we can help you!

acf.PH_sub_heading: Feeling limited in your ability to go limited? Don’t worry we’re here to help!
acf.PH_copy:
We aim to make becoming a limited company as smooth and easy as possible for you. That being said, a few things may seem a little confusing for someone who’s new to this kind of thing. That’s why we’ve set up this page to take you through each of the 6 steps of the process and answer the most commonly asked questions.

Remember: if in doubt, click on the button in the bottom right corner to chat to one of our advisors- they’ll be more than happy to put you on the straight and true!

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: Here you’ll see if the name you chose is acceptable
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
Obviously if it’s already taken or too similar to an existing company name then it won’t be accepted and you’ll have to come up with a new one. There are also certain restrictions that you must abide by in naming such as obscenities, belying a connection to the royal family or denoting qualifications. To see a full list of the criteria you must work with, check out this Companies House page.

The rest of page one is self explanatory- just enter the number of directors who will run your company, your details and then click the agree to terms and conditions button (please have a read first- it’s a bit of legalese that explains the use of our service).

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: The second page has a little more depth to it.
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
You’ll first be asked for your registered office address. You’ll be asked for several addresses throughout the process and although they’re for different purposes they may well be the same in some cases.  Your registered office address goes to Companies House when you register and will be where official communications from Companies House and HMRC go. This will often be your accountant’s address.

The next step is Corporation Tax, which may sound like a scary section but it’s simply there to make things easier for you.

  • You’ll first be asked if you intend to make your company dormant. Generally this will be ‘no’. The only reason you would say ‘yes’ to this is if you don’t plan to start trading right away- this will reserve the company name and have everything ready to go when you want to start trading.
  • When you form a company you have to register for corporation tax with HMRC within 3 months of starting to trade. We’ve made it really easy to kill two birds with one stone- just say ‘yes’ you’d like to register for corporation tax, then fill in your details. It’s all straight forward enough, although you will be asked for your trading address. This is the location that you actually do business from (i.e an office, shop or home address).

The third section here asks you for your company details. This is essentially what your company does, what it consists of, and approximately what it can make.

  • Working out your estimated taxable profit. This is what your company can potentially make if you take away any tax free exemptions and is based on ranges, so you can give an idea of your company’s earning potential.
  • The number of employees- the number of people on your payroll (not including directors).
  • You’ll then be asked if your business involves investment, retail or import/export. If the answer is ‘no’ then you’re eligible to join Crunch and reap the benefits of free limited company formation. If the answer is ‘yes’ then you can still form a limited company, but you will have to pay a £10 fee (this is the registration fee at Companies House).
  • Do you use a factoring service? One would assume you know what this is if you’re using it, but just to clarify-  a factoring service is a bit like a payday loan for invoices. i.e if you send an invoice for £1000 that will be paid in 90 days, the factoring service will buy the invoice from you and give you the money straight up (minus their fee- so they might take a £50 fee and give you £950) then they’ll receive the invoice total in said 90 days which pays off your debt. Simply select ‘yes’ or ‘no’.

Remember: if in doubt, simply click on the button in the bottom right corner to chat to one of our advisors. We’re there to help!

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: In this section you’ll need to give us the details of the directors of your company.
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
The first director is normally you, so simply fill in your details into all fields.

  • For the home address you can put your actual home address or your registered office address. This is for our records.
  • Further on in this section you’ll be asked for your service address. This will serve as your official contact address for HMRC and Companies House. You can give your home address, or, if you wish to keep your residential addresses confidential, your registered office address/ virtual office address (a purchased office address).
  • We will also ask you to supply us with 3 pieces of authentication info. These are pieces of personal information known only to you and us that we can use to identify you when speaking over the phone.  You can choose from a selection of what you’d prefer to share and find easy to remember.
  • We will lastly ask if you will be a shareholder in the new company. We will explain more on this later- for now just check the box if you plan to be a shareholder.

Once you’ve added the first director, add additional directors (you can add up to four) by pressing the pink ‘+ Add Director’ button and repeating the process for each director.

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: Part 1
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
Here’s where we’ll establish the division of shares in the company. This is something everyone starting a limited company must do. It might look a tad confusing, but fear not- we’re here to explain it all in plain English.

Firstly let’s get the basic lingo down

Shares are basically the division of ownership of the company. For example, a company has 4 shares and they are owned by 1 person- that person owns 100% of the company; however if 2 people own 2 shares each then they each have 50% of the company.

Share value is how much each of those shares are worth.

Share capital is the total money invested into the company to create those shares.

Shareholders are people who own the company, which is divided into shares. Note: you don’t have to be a director to be a shareholder.

Let’s talk about how to designate shares (AKA what you need to do on this page)

Every limited company must have at least one share. If you are the sole director of the new company, then the easiest thing to do is create one share at the value of £1. This will give you 100% of the company with a share capital of £1. Nice and simple right? This is what we generally recommend when starting out.

Similarly, if there are two directors then you can make two shares at the value of £1 each. This will give both of you 50% of the company with a share capital of £2.

If you want an uneven divide of the company (i.e the same two directors but one of them owns more of the company than the other) you can create 10 shares for the company at £1 each. This gives you a solid 10 shares to create the divide you want. You could divide the 10 shares so that one director has 6 shares and the other has 4 shares. This means the first director has 60% of the company and the other has 40%. The director with 60% owns more of the company so has controlling interest (more on that later).

There is no such thing as half a share, so if you want an even more specific division of the company, then you can have 100 shares at £1 and then divide them accordingly. If you have multiple shareholders then it’s probably the easiest way to split the company shares.

With us so far? Remember, if it’s still a bit baffling you can always chat to one of our advisors by clicking the button in the bottom right hand corner of this page.

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: Part 2
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
All shares equal money that must be paid into the company. That money then gets locked into the company as share capital. This is essentially you ‘buying’ the company.

It’s tempting to be flashy and make a million shares at £10 a share, but you will have to pay £10 million into the company by the end of the tax year (pretty ambitious for most start-ups).

Rule of thumb: You can always issue more shares later, so there’s no point being any fancier than you need to when starting out. i.e you create 1 share at £1. You designate that share to you as the sole director. That promised £1 you put into the company bank account. You now own 100% of the company. The same principles apply to any division of shares.

What do shares actually mean?

In return for putting your money into the company- you receive shares, which basically give you:

  • Your say in the affairs of the company or voting rights. More shares=more say. Whoever has the most votes has the most say which is known as having controlling interests in the company.
  • Your right to vote dividends from the company’s profits (after tax). This is basically the amount of profit money each shareholder personally receives per share they own. Again more shares=more money.

You can also get more elaborate with share classes. This basically gives some shares more rights than others. That being said, they’re not required for new limited companies so we have left it out of the forming process. You can always delve into it later if you wish.

Obviously these are more relevant if the company has multiple shareholders/directors. If you are the sole director then you will own all the shares, meaning you can do whatever you please.

Remember: if in doubt, just click on the button in the bottom right corner to chat to one of our advisors.

Because it’s your decision on how you split the company shares, we can’t tell you what you should do. However, we will help you to understand it to the best of our ability so that you can make well informed decisions.

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: This page is nice and straightforward.
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
Companies House need to know who’s setting up the limited company- even if you aren’t a director or shareholder. If that’s the case then simply fill in your details.  If you sign up with Crunch you can make it easy by using our office address (just click the ‘Use Crunch’s Address’ button).

If you are a director or shareholder then you will have already entered your details earlier in the process so all you need to do is click the button with your name on and the form will fill out automatically. Viola!

You can also take a look at the Privacy Policy near the top of the page if you’re curious about what happens with personal information (don’t worry it’s nothing shady).

You’re almost done…

You’ll need to confirm your information on the next page to  ensure that what you’ve entered is correct.  It’s much easier to correct things now than after the company has been formed.  You’ll get an overview of each section- simply click the ‘Edit’ button of each the change anything.

When you’re certain everything is good to go… click ‘Confirm’

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: Finally, you’ll be taken to the payments page.
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
Everyone must pay the £10 Companies House registration fee, however if you sign up to Crunch for your accounting needs within the first 40 days of forming your company, you’ll be waived the £25 Crunch setup fee AND refunded the £10 Companies House registration fee- you can’t say better than that!

Crunch have been specially created for the needs of small businesses (just like yours), with easy to use 24/7 real time accounting software and unlimited support from our team of expert accountants. You’ll also get a wealth of business resources right at your fingertips. Everything you need, all in one place- ready to help you take your newly formed limited company to dizzying heights!

Whether you decide to go it alone or crack on with Crunch, put in your payment details and click ‘confirm’ to process the payment. Then hey presto- you’re all done!

You’ll receive an email telling you your application has been submitted to Companies House. If everything’s fine with your submission, you should get another email telling you your incorporation is complete. This will normally take about 5 hours (but being an office- if you applied on a weekend or in the evening it will take longer).
Congratulations- Your brand new limited company is all ready to go!

You can also download our guide on starting your own limited company here.

Our affiliate network allows thousands of people just like you, to turn their contacts and site traffic into cold hard cash! We want you to be one of that happy number. The rules are simple: every time you send us a new client, you get a cool £100 straight into your bank account!

The great news is, we’ve done all the work for you! All the banners and gizmos you need to promote us are ready and waiting on our affiliate network, so all you need to do is put them on your website, kick back and watch the money roll in.

Refer a Friend

If you’re a client, you don’t need a website to earn rewards. If you know someone who needs a hand with their accounts – put them in touch with us to see if we can help. Any referral who successfully becomes a client is welcomed with a £25 Amazon voucher, while you’ll get either £50 worth of Amazon vouchers ​​or​ a month free!

Over the last five years our client base has expanded to over 8,000 people thanks to our existing customers recommending us!

acf.SH_heading: How we calculate average day rates
acf.SH_sub_heading: So you know exactly how much to charge
acf.SH_copy:
We’ve analysed anonymised data from thousands of our freelancer and contractor clients to come up with the definitive day rates guide, based on over 1.8 million billed days across the UK since the beginning of 2013.

The day rate data used to build this map is pulled directly from our online accounting software, giving an accurate picture of how much freelancers and contractors across the UK are billing their clients every day.

The map is based on a sample size of up to 4,700 limited companies (depending on the time scale and region selected). A region must have a large number of records within it to generate a result to prevent potentially misleading low sample rates. The result displayed is the median day rate, rounded to the nearest pound.
acf.FH_sub_heading: How this map can help you
acf.FH_copy:
“How much should I charge?” is one of the first questions most business owners ask themselves when starting out. There are a variety of excellent sample surveys available to answer that question, but up until now nothing offering analysis of a large, national dataset.

With thousands of clients up and down the UK, we are in a unique position to offer this data to freelancers and contractors just starting out.

This day rate data is also invaluable for benchmarking – an important part of business development. Freelancers, contractors and other professionals who sell their time often find it difficult to get a picture of the market at large. This map is designed to offer just that – a clear view of the national and regional day rate landscape.

acf.PH_sub_heading: The sky’s the limit when you go limited
acf.PH_copy:
When you’re a sole trader, it’s just you plying your trade out there in the big bad world. Whatever you do it’s all on your head. Some people prefer it that way.

But you’re also missing out on a plethora (that’s right a plethora) of brilliant benefits that come with making your business a limited company.

Think about it…

  • Potential for more take home pay
  • Greater borrowing power to expand your business
  • A company status that can attract bigger business
  • The ability to work with more agencies (many won’t work with sole traders)
  • The same kind of flexibility you had as a sole trader (you’re the boss after all)
  • You’ll also get limited liability- legal protection that separates your own finances from that of your company in case things go unexpectedly fruit shaped (not that they will- we’ve got faith in you)

Applying only takes a few minutes and we’ll take care of the rest for you. All you’ll need to do is think of an awesome name for your new company!

You’ll also get unlimited support from our in-house team of expert accountants, with professional advice tailored to the specific needs of you and your business. Plus 24/7 access to our fantastic online software, allowing you to easily keep an eye on everything wherever you are, so you can focus on what really matters- making your business a success.

acf.PH_sub_heading: How Crunch stacks up against other accountants
acf.PH_copy:
In May 2015, we commissioned OnePoll, an independent market research company, to undertake a survey of self-employed workers and small business owners to understand their accountancy spending habits and customer experience.

The survey audience was selected to be a fair representation of Crunch’s target audience. 80% were one-person businesses, 20% micro-business owners (up to 10 people) and 100% of them were Limited Companies. It was stipulated that all must use an external accountant who is not a friend or family member, to avoid any skewing of results.

Are you paying more than you should?

More than two thirds of UK freelancers, contractors and micro-business owners are paying more than they need to for their accountancy service. The pockets of Crunch clients are already feeling the financial benefit of using our service.
acf.SH_copy: Worryingly, 80% of the self-employed and micro-business owners do not know how much they owe the taxman today, making prudent financial planning difficult. Crunch clients can see how much they owe in real time, every time they log into their account.
acf.TH_copy: Nearly two thirds of the self-employed and micro-business owners are unable to speak to their accountant immediately. In times of need you really don’t want to wait, that’s why Crunch clients are able to speak to someone immediately, with no appointment necessary.
acf.AC_copy: Call us now on 0333 311 8000 or request a callback for when you’re free.

acf.SH_sub_heading: You can make extra revenue with Crunch
acf.SH_copy:
Do you run a recruitment agency that deals with freelancers, contractors and consultants? If so, you can make extra revenue by joining the Crunch Affiliate network.

If you have candidates who need help with their accounting, please email partners@crunch.co.uk to discuss how we can work together.
acf.TSH_copy:
We’re growing all the time, so we’re always on the look out for the best talent to join Crunch. In fact, we’re expanding so fast we’ve got an internal team that’s dedicated to recruitment. This team will source potential employees, get in touch to arrange interviews, and contact candidates afterwards.

We don’t do all the heavy lifting, though. From time to time we work with pre-selected agencies to help us recruit those hard to fill roles. This does mean, however, that we are not interested in working with agencies unless we contact you. It’s nothing personal, it’s just how we do things.

Please don’t call us unsolicited, the answer will always be no.
acf.TSH_step_1: If we need a new agency, we’ll come looking for the best ones that are relevant to the roles we’re recruiting.
acf.TSH_step_2: Please don’t repeatedly call us trying to pitch your agency’s services. It stops us answering our most important calls – those from our clients.
acf.TSH_step_3: All of our roles are posted on our careers page, we’re not hiding others that need your help.

acf.FH_sub_heading: Accountancy support for Umbrella Company contractors
acf.FH_copy:
If you’re working as a contractor for an Umbrella Company you might be paying more tax than you need to. By signing up to Crunch and creating your own limited company you’ll have greater tax efficiency, plus you’ll limit your personal liability.

We pair an accredited team with simple to use online tools that make accounting as clear and straightforward as possible. It only takes a few minutes to set up your Limited Company with Crunch, and then you’ll instantly have the best legal protection for your business. We’ll deal with the taxman for you, take care of all the paperwork, and we can even do your Self Assessment for you.
acf.FWT_copy:
My agency told me I have to work through an Umbrella company! Is this true?

There is never a legal reason why you must work through an Umbrella company, although employment agencies often recommend them to receive referral fees. Often if you insist on working as a sole trader or through a limited company the agency will allow it – although sometimes they’ll refuse.

Are Umbrella companies easier than running your own limited company?

Yes – but you sacrifice a lot for that ease-of-use. Umbrella companies are often seen as a simple solution for those who aren’t planning to be self-employed in the long-term; those who are between permanent jobs, for example. Those looking to set up their own business or work for themselves for a long time are better off with a limited company.

acf.PH_sub_heading: Let’s get the ball rolling...
acf.PH_copy:
You’re on the cusp of joining thousands of freelancers, contractors, and micro-business owners who have revolutionised the way they handle their business finances. They have the freedom they need to focus on succeeding in business – and now it’s time for you to become one of them.

Signing up is done over the phone in two parts. One call with your Advisor as an introduction and to start the registration process; and a second with your Client Manager to chat about your company so we can determine exactly what you need from our service and how we can help.
acf.SH_sub_heading: Making sure your accounting is made to measure
acf.SH_copy:
The second call will be with your new Client Manager (who will be your point of contact from then on) to discuss your company in more depth so we can tailor your account.

If you’re just starting your company then we’ll set everything up for you, from registering your business to sorting out your payroll.

However, if you’re coming to us as an existing limited company then, in order to make the transition as seamless as possible, you need to give us information on your:

  • Company
  • Directors (including yourself)
  • VAT
  • Corporation tax
  • Payroll (PAYE)
  • HMRC Gateway details
  • Previous accountant or agent’s detail

 

Alternatively, just get all your info from your current accountant.

Please ensure you have this information before the call. We won’t be able to set up your account without it.

Voilà!

Once we have what we need, we’ll activate your new Crunch account and you’ll be able to start enjoying hassle-free accounting straight away.
acf.HCL_heading: Sign up with your existing company
acf.HCL_copy:
Once your ID check has passed and your subscription is up and running, a signup account manager will call you to discuss your company details in order to set up your Crunch account correctly. This will take around 20 minutes.

We need to ask you about how your company is structured in order to configure your Crunch account correctly. This ensures you will meet your regulatory obligations and legal responsibilities.

Giving us your salary and personal tax details means we can advise on the most tax efficient way to withdraw money from your company and assist with the filing of your annual self assessment.

We need to know about your employees to start running your employee payroll and RTI filings to HMRC.

We need to be able to get in touch with your previous accountant or agent in order to seek Professional Clearance and obtain historical information.

TS_features.post_title: Set up your limited company in minutes

acf.PH_supplementary_copy:
Before you buy a pair of jeans, you need to ensure they’re a good fit. We believe accounting is no different. In the first call, your Advisor will introduce you to our service and see if what we can offer you is right for your needs.

If all is well and you wish to go ahead, then you’ll firstly need to supply us with the following information and ID so we can run anti money laundering checks (required under current Government regulations) on yourself, and any other directors or shareholders involved with your business. If you haven’t started your business yet then just send us this information for the directors and shareholders you plan to start the company with.

You’ll also need to read and agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.

This should all be very straightforward and take about 10 minutes- just ensure you have all the information you need before the call. Or you can save time and email the information to your Advisor beforehand.
acf.TSH_copy:
To get started you need to make a quick call with your advisor, this should take around 10 minutes. We need to carry out regulatory ID checks required under current Money Laundering Regulations. You’ll also need to read and agree to our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy, then we will verify your identity.

Your advisor will run an ID check on you and all other directors of the company along with any shareholders who have over 25% shareholding. If you don’t have a limited company yet, this check will be run on the directors you want to set up the company with and the shareholders who you want to have over 25% shareholding.
acf.TSH_step_1: We’ll collect your (plus all directors and 25%+ shareholders) details for ID checks. You’ll also need to read and accept our Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.
acf.TSH_step_2: A slightly longer conversation where we will go into your business in more detail and make sure your account is set up as you want and need it.
acf.TSH_step_3_heading: Then you’ll be set up and  ready to roll!
acf.TSH_step_3: That’s it. You are now free to explore and use your account!

acf.PH_sub_heading: We’re so much more than just accountants
acf.PH_copy:
We started with a simple purpose: to make you successful. To help fledgling entrepreneurs earn a living doing something they’re really passionate about, and to make breaking free easier for the millions of people stuck in jobs they hate.

It’s a journey we’ve been on ourselves. We took a business idea by the horns, and now we’re in the privileged position of helping tens of thousands of others do the same. Our success has heart and soul behind it, and we want you to have the same.

We’re now one of Brighton’s biggest technology and financial services businesses, and our entire service is run from our HQ in central Brighton. We’re not interested in traditional accountancy firm hierarchies; we recruit the best people around, train them well, and let them do what they do best.
acf.SH_copy:
A technology sector stalwart, Michael has held management positions at some of the world’s largest digital firms, including AOL, eBay and PayPal. This culminated in Michael being named CEO of Skype in 2007 and Chairman in 2008, before his departure at the end of 2009. Michael provides top-level guidance to the Crunch board, as well as invaluable mentorship to our management team.

Darren Fell, co-founder and Managing Director

Bored after 14 years in the telecoms industry, Darren founded email marketing company Pure360 in 2001. Pure360 successfully scaled and became one of the top three specialist digital marketing firms in the UK. In 2007, having suffered at the hands of traditional accountants, Darren turned his attention to the world of online accounting, and Crunch was the result.
acf.TH_heading3: Steve Crouch, co-founder and Financial Director
acf.TH_copy:
Steve is a 30-year veteran of the tax and accounting sector, having spent many years working within HMRC before eventually setting up his own firm in 1991, and co-founding Crunch in 2007. Steve is the brains behind the Crunch accounting software, and leads our team of expert accountants, providing a wealth of guidance and insight attained through his many years in practice.

Paul Birch, Crunch Investor

Paul co-founded giant social network Bebo, which he and his brother sold to AOL for $850 million in 2008. After suffering at the hands of a traditional accountant during his days IT contracting in the City of London, Paul fell in love with the idea of Crunch. Paul brings his years of experience in the tech sector to the Crunch team, and influences every aspect of our business.
acf.TH_review: “Quick and easy, I can concentrate on my business and there’s no nasty surprises at the end of the year.” – Clare Devlin, Devlin Design Limited

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: Traditional small business accounting is broken
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
In 2007 veteran accountant Steve Crouch and entrepreneur Darren Fell, himself having experienced the many shortfalls of traditional accountancy firms, set out to fix it. They created a fairly priced, all-inclusive service for everyone, uniting easy to use software with unlimited in-house support. No gaps. No fuss. Accounting for the modern era.

In 2009 Crunch was born, offering a game-changing online accounting service for less than half the price of traditional firms.

Today we’re a top 100 accountancy firm providing one of the fastest, most comprehensive accounting services on the market – and we’re still around half the price of our traditional competitors.

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: And we’ll never stop innovating
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
These days our service is much more than just accountancy. Company formation, professional insurance, office space, legal support – we’ve got everything you need to make your business boom.

We’ve poured millions into our technology and accountancy service, and we have no plans to let up. We have no greedy shareholders, and the money we make goes directly back into the business to develop our products and ensure that our clients always get the best service at a great price.

It’s our business to help your business.

acf.BF_title: Inside Crunch
acf.FKP_point_1_copy: We're serious about recruiting only the best people
acf.FKP_point_2_copy: We're the only accountancy firm that develops software in-house
acf.FKP_point_3_copy: Our accountants and account managers are fanatical about your success
acf.FKP_point_4_copy: Our pricing is flat, transparent, and amongst the cheapest in the country

acf.FH_copy:
The sole trader route is often preferred by those just starting out. However, working through a limited company is the best way to protect yourself legally and maximise income.

Previously, the fear of bureaucracy and fines have kept many from going limited, but with Crunch these extra responsibilities are taken care of. You don’t even have to worry about incorporation – sign up to Crunch and your Client Manager will handle your company formation in no time. Want to know more? Check out our useful guide for starting a limited company.

  • Tax efficiency – more take-home pay!
  • We’ll deal with the taxman on your behalf – avoid the accounting jargon and HMRC’s hold times!
  • Limited liability to protect your personal assets
  • All the extra limited company paperwork included in our monthly fee
  • We can do your Self Assessment too!

tile_group.tile_group_copy: From business insurance to legal services; from mortgage assistance to freelancer banks – we’ve got everything you need in one place, complete with our seal of approval.

AH_alternating_headline.AH_sub_heading: All your business needs, all in one place
AH_alternating_headline.AH_copy:
Finding reliable, competitively priced suppliers and services for your business can be confusing and expensive. That’s why, since we launched in 2009, we’ve been on a mission to hunt down the very best small business providers to complement our accounting service. Our partners are the perfect fit for micro-businesses, and you’ll find them all in the marketplace.

We have personal relationships with all our Marketplace partners, we use many of them ourselves, and we can vouch for the quality of their services. Thanks to the buying power of the Crunch community you’ll also find healthy discounts on many services.

acf.BF_title: The latest from our blog

acf.FH_sub_heading: Not sure if you are inside or outside of IR35? Our calculator can help.
acf.FH_copy:
Do you provide your services through a limited company? If the answer’s yes, HMRC need to be convinced that you’re not using your limited company to disguise a relationship with your client which would otherwise be that of employment.

Don’t be alarmed if you’re confused – so are most of HMRC and the MPs overseeing the legislation – that’s why it’s best to make certain your limited company’s position with some professional help and an IR35 test.

To help you navigate the IR35 minefield, use our IR35 calculator to determine your risk of being caught out by the legislation.

Need more help? You can download our useful guide, or you can get a pass/fail overview by letting our experts review your contracts.

acf.SH_sub_heading: We make accounting simple and easy to understand
acf.SH_copy:
Over the last five years our client base has expanded to over 6000 people thanks to our existing customers recommending us to new individuals.

If you know someone who needs a hand with their accounts, put them in touch with us to see if we can help. Accounting can seem like a daunting challenge, but there’s nothing more reassuring than a recommendation from a friend.

Any client successfully referred to us is welcomed with a £25 Amazon voucher.
acf.TSH_sub_heading: Grab rewards when you refer a friend
acf.TSH_copy:
We love that our clients enjoy using Crunch so much that they tell their friends about us, so it’s important that we say thank you. Every time you successfully refer someone to us we’ll treat you to a special gift of your choice.

You can choose either a free month of Crunch (no matter your subscription level) or £50 worth of Amazon vouchers to spend on whatever you want. There’s no limit on referrals, so if you recommend us to enough people, then your account could pay for itself!

Start referring today by following the three easy steps on the right.
acf.TSH_step_1: Log in to your account and click the ‘get Crunch for free’ button in the top-right of your screen.
acf.TSH_step_2: Email your friend direct, post to social networks, or grab a banner ad.
acf.TSH_step_3: Choose a free month of Crunch or a £50 Amazon voucher. Your friend gets a £25 voucher too!

acf.PH_sub_heading: Upgrade to a modern accounting service
acf.PH_copy:
Make your accounts easier to manage and save money by switching from a traditional accountant to Crunch. We pair our accredited accountants with specialist online software to provide a modern, simple to use accountancy service.

Getting started is easy as we will contact your old accountant and move across all of your previous invoices and expenses, plus with our straightforward import tools you can upload old information quickly. It only takes a few minutes to move online and change accountants, so why not contact one of our advisors to get started?

You’re never on your own at Crunch as we give you your very own Client Manager, they’ll answer all of your questions and let you know how to stay tax-efficient. With an accountant at your beck and call and sophisticated bookkeeping tools, you’ll have more time to get on with business.
acf.PH_review: “Very good service, good price in comparison with previous accountant. Recommend to other small businesses.” – Steven Duncan, SDNUK Limited

acf.PH_copy:
You can keep a keen eye on your bookkeeping by upgrading your accounting to Crunch. With our easy to use online software you can look after your accounts more quickly than on a conventional spreadsheet, and you’ll keep just as much control over the numbers.

By joining Crunch you’ll get unlimited accounting advice from your very own Client Manager. They’re on hand to offer guidance tailored specifically to your company, and ensure that you meet all of your tax obligations and deadlines.

Free up more time to focus on your business and manage your day-to-day bookkeeping, simply by using our online accounting software. We can even look after your bookkeeping when you sign up to our Premium package. If you don’t want to go Premium, fear not- you can add our bookkeeping service to your Standard or Plus package as a bolt-on. We make bookkeeping a breeze whichever way you go!
acf.PH_review: “Very helpful and keep things easy.” – Jamie Regan, JR Consultancy & Training Ltd

TS_features.post_title: Know your numbers at a glance

acf.PH_sub_heading: Time saving tools to tame your bookkeeping (and save your sanity)
acf.PH_copy:
When your business is booming it’s hard to find the time to stay on top of your bookkeeping. That’s why our service has been specially developed to help make bookkeeping a breeze for freelancers, contractors and small businesses.

With our easy-to-use software there’s no need to stress – day-to-day bookkeeping is quick and effortless. You can manage your business finances in real time, at any time, in just a few little clicks. What’s more you can do it anywhere, whether you’re on the job, on the move, or on the sofa!

Our mobile apps make your bookkeeping even more of a breeze. Simply take a picture of a receipt to record an expense, and claim business mileage when you’re out and about.

By having your software, accountants, and bookkeeping all in one place, we can keep the price low and the service high. It’s much more efficient than hiring your own bookkeeper.

Go Premium and let us take care of all your bookkeeping for you! (Don’t worry, our bookkeeping service is also available as an add-on to Standard and Plus clients should you want to take advantage of it!)
acf.PH_supplementary_sub_heading: Everything you need to know, in one handy guide.
acf.PH_supplementary_copy: Download your free guide to bookkeeping today.

acf.PH_sub_heading: Easily switch to our accredited online team
acf.PH_copy:
Limited companies can switch to Crunch easily and start enjoying stress-free accounting and bookkeeping. If you’re looking to move accountants we make the whole process simple, from contacting your existing accountant to importing your previous invoices and expenses.

In no time you’ll be able to get unlimited support from our expert team of accountants, plus you’ll get to use our exclusive online accounting software. You’ll never miss a deadline again and you’ll always have a clear overview of your cash flow, making bookkeeping and finance management a breeze.

Our accredited accountants work with thousands of limited companies, so you can rest assured that you’re getting the best advice. With your own Client Manager on hand to help you with Corporation Tax returns, Year End filing and more, you’ll never have to worry about accounting again.
acf.PH_review: “Fantastically useful service, being able to input and review all your company’s finances as you go.” – Luke Williams, Onedub Ltd

You’ll free up more time to develop your new business and you can rest assured that your finances and bookkeeping are all in order. Our accredited team look after hundreds of startups all over the UK, and you’ll have your own Client Manager on hand to guide you through the formation process, incorporation, payroll and anything else you need.

The exclusive Crunch software has been designed with startup users in mind, so you’ll find it easier than ever to manage your cashflow. acf.PH_copy:

acf.SH_copy:

You can arrange a callback from one of our team at a convenient time, and they’ll answer all of your questions and point you in the right direction.

With three different packages available, we have a range of solutions to suit most freelancers, small businesses and contractors- from the comprehensive Premium service including bookkeeping and all the shiny bells and whistles, to the more basic Standard Package or the happy medium of the Plus Package (both with the option of additional bells and whistles to tailor your account the way you want it). So if you’re looking to step out from underneath an umbrella company, or switch from the role of a sole trader, contact our team for expert support.
